review.title: Scalable Discovery of Time-Series Shapelets
review.abstract: Time-series classification is an important problem for the data mining community due to the wide range of application domains involving time-series data. A recent paradigm, called shapelets, represents patterns that are highly predictive for the target variable. Shapelets are discovered by measuring the prediction accuracy of a set of potential (shapelet) candidates. The candidates typically consist of all the segments of a dataset, therefore, the discovery of shapelets is computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel method that avoids measuring the prediction accuracy of similar candidates in Euclidean distance space, through an online clustering pruning technique. In addition, our algorithm incorporates a supervised shapelet selection that filters out only those candidates that improve classification accuracy. Empirical evidence on 45 datasets from the UCR collection demonstrate that our method is 3-4 orders of magnitudes faster than the fastest existing shapelet-discovery method, while providing better prediction accuracy.
histories: Under review in the journal "Knowledge and Information Systems" (KAIS)
review.COMMENTS: Under review in the journal "Knowledge and Information Systems" (KAIS)

metadata.title: Scalable Discovery of Time-Series Shapelets

sections.text: This year, it has reached the point where it will be able to retaliate.

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text: A large pool of candidates from all segments of a dataset were assessed as potential shapelet candidates, while the minimum distance from series to shapelets was used as a predictive feature, and the best performing candidates were rated on the basis of the criteria for obtaining information about the target. Subsequently, other predictive quality metrics were also worked out, such as Kruskal-Wallis or Mood's median [6] and F-Stats [8]. The minimum distance between time series and a set of shapelets can be categorized as instrumental data transformation (dimensionality reduction) and is referred to as shapelet-transformed data [2]. Standard classifiers have been shown to be competitive with shapelet-transformed predictors [6].

sections.heading: III. SCALABLE SHAPELET DISCOVERY
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Distances of Shapelets to Series as Classification Features
sections.text: While our method can work with a series of arbitrary lengths, we define a single length M to simplify mathematical formalism. Distances from formulas to series can be used as classification characteristics, also known as shapelet-transformed characteristics [2], [6]. The distance of a shapelet of a candidate to the next segment of a series can be perceived as a degree of belonging to that particular shapelet. Equations 1 and 2 formalize the minimum distances between a shapelet s and the data set T as vector of euclidean dial distances (D) between the shapelet and the next segment of each series. (The notation Va: b denotes a sub-sequence of vector V from the a-th element to the b-th element.) MinDist (s, T): = D (s, T1) D (shapelet), D (2...

sections.heading: B. Quantification of Similarity Using a Distance Threshold
sections.text: Since series of the same class follow a similar structure, similar patterns are repeated over time series of the same class. Similarities can also be observed between time series of different classes, since classes are often discriminated against by differences in small sub-sequences, rather than by the global structure. Consequently, we overturn the hypothesis that existing state-of-the-art techniques, which comprehensively search all candidates, inefficiently take into account many very similar patterns. Figure 2 illustrates the distribution of distances among arbitrary pairs of candidate segments from different time series in the UCR collection of data sets [16]. As shown in Figure (a), the distribution of distances is highly sketched, indicating that most candidates are very similar to each other. However, threshold separation at similarity distance is required in order to use segments as similar or not.

sections.heading: C. Main Method: Scalable Discovery of Time-series Shapelets
sections.text: The scalable discovery of the Shapelets time series follows the two primary principles of this work: i) pruning similar candidates, and ii) on-the-fly supervised selection of shapelets. The rationality of these principles is based on the knowledge that the majority of candidates from each specific candidate series resemble candidates, whether candidates in other rows of the same dataset. Therefore, it is mathematically not optimal to measure the quality of the many very similar candidates. Instead, we aim to consider only a small core of non-redundant candidates. Algorithm 2: DiscoverShapelets: Scalable discovery of ShapeletsData: Time Series Data T, Labels Y, RN Distance Threshold Percentile p. [1,., 100], Piecewise Aggregate Approximation Ratio.

sections.heading: D. Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA)
sections.text: The Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) is a dimensionality reduction method that shortens time series by averaging neighboring values. [18] Algorithm 3 illustrates how the time series of a dataset can be compressed by a ratio r. If r = 14 then all four consecutive points are replaced by their averages, PAA significantly reduces the detection time of shapelets, as in Figure 6 (sub-Figure b) for selected datasets. On the other hand, Figure a) shows that classification accuracy does not deteriorate significantly because time series data often have a redundancy in length and can be compressed. sections.heading: E. Algorithmic Analysis of the Runtime Speed-Up
sections.text: The duration of the Shapelet detection algorithms that examine candidates between series segments is limited by the number of candidates in a dataset. Given N -many training series of length M, the total number of Shapelet candidates has an order of magnitude of O (NM2), while the time required to find the best Shapelet candidates is O (N2M4). Please note that the detection time is square in relation to the number of candidates. Total time of complexity applied in O (N2 (PAA) is to reduce the length of time series by a ratio.

sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Baselines
sections.text: In order to evaluate the efficiency of the proposed method, known as SD, the fastest state-of-the-art form finding methods were selected: 1) Logical Shapelet [4] (referred to as LS): promotes the original form finding method [1] by an order of magnitude, by means of: (i) caching and reusing calculations and (ii) applying permissible truncation of the search space [4]. 2) Fast Shapelet [5] (referred to as FS): is a modern method that suggests a random projection technique for SAX representation by filtering potential candidates [5]. FS has shown that LS form finding time is reduced by two to three orders of magnitude [5]. 3) Improved Fast Shapelet (referred to as FS + +): is a variation of FS that we have created for the sake of time.

sections.heading: B. Setup and Reproducibility
sections.text: To demonstrate the acceleration performance of the proposed Shapelet discovery method, we use the popular collection of time series data sets from the UCR collection [16]. For completeness, we experimented with all 45 data sets in the collection. Data set statistics are presented in Table I. For each data set, the number of instances of series, the number of classes and the length of time series are displayed. Our Scalable Shapelet discovery method, called SD, requires the matching of two parameters, the aggregation ratio r and the threshold p. The parameters were performed for each data set by cross-validation. The combination (r, p) that yielded the highest accuracy in the train was selected. In case of equal tensile accuracy of the values, we were selected the highest (r, p) values.

sections.heading: D. Competitive Prediction Accuracy
sections.text: Most scalability work suggests speeding up learning time by sacrificing a fraction of predictive accuracy. In contrast, our results show that our method is both faster and more accurate than baselines; the winning method that achieves the highest accuracy on each data set (in each row) is differentiated in bold; our method has more wins than baselines (21 wins against 13 of the second best method) and also a better ranking (1,889 versus 2,178 of the second best method); the improvement in accuracy results from the common interaction of accepted shapelets as predictors (distance matrix X in algorithm 2), while baselines measure the quality of each shapelet separately without taking into account their interactions [1], [4], [5].

sections.heading: E. Speed-Up Analysis
sections.text: s detection time in the x-axis and the logarithm of the detection time of each baseline as the y-axis. As can be easily observed from the illustrative order lines, SD is 4 to 5 orders of magnitude faster than the Logical Shapelet (LS) and 3 to 4 orders of magnitude faster than the Fast Shapelet (FS). The datasets in which LS exceeds the 24-hour threshold are displayed in light blue. Furthermore, FS + + is faster than FS because it iterates over fewer shape length sizes, but is still 1 to 2 orders of magnitude slower than SD. The diagrams on the right represent scatter plots of classification accuracy of SD over baselines. While it is generally better than our method, FS is greater than FS.

sections.heading: F. A Modular Decomposition of the Performance
sections.text: We have seen that our proposed method, SD, significantly exceeds the state of the art in terms of runtime = does not produce better predictive accuracy. However, there are a few questions that can be addressed to our method, such as: 1) What fraction of the SD runtime shortening is attributed to the novel candidate and what fraction of the PAA compression? 2) To what extent does circumcision imply a deterioration in predictive accuracy? To address these analytical questions, we will dissect our method in a modular manner. Our method, SD, performs both a PAA approximation and a circumcision according to the parameters r, p provided in Table II. To isolate the effects of compression and circumcision, we create four variants of our method, namely the permutations "With / Without PAA compression" and "Without PAA compression."

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Shapelets represent discriminatory segments of a time series dataset, and the distances from time series to shapelets are proving to be successful characteristics for classification. Currently, the discovery of shapelets takes place by testing candidates from the segments (sub-sequences) of the time series. As the number of candidate segments is large, the time series community has made efforts to speed up the discovery time of shapelets. In this paper, a new method has been proposed that truncates candidates based on a distance threshold to other similar candidates previously considered. In parallel, a novel supervised selection filters those shapelets that increase classification accuracy. We have empirically demonstrated that our method is 3-4 orders of magnitude faster than the fastest existing shapelet detection methods while providing better predictive accuracy.

metadata.abstractText: Time-series classification is an important problem for the data mining community due to the wide range of application domains involving time-series data. A recent paradigm, called shapelets, represents patterns that are highly predictive for the target variable. Shapelets are discovered by measuring the prediction accuracy of a set of potential (shapelet) candidates. The candidates typically consist of all the segments of a dataset, therefore, the discovery of shapelets is computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel method that avoids measuring the prediction accuracy of similar candidates in Euclidean distance space, through an online clustering pruning technique. In addition, our algorithm incorporates a supervised shapelet selection that filters out only those candidates that improve classification accuracy. Empirical evidence on 45 datasets from the UCR collection demonstrate that our method is 3-4 orders of magnitudes faster than the fastest existing shapelet-discovery method, while providing better prediction accuracy.
